Lumpectomy is more ideal for smaller tumors while mastectomy is ideal for tumors near the chest wall or larger than 5 cm. Lumpectomy can be preferred for cosmetic reasons(there will be more tissue left for reconstruction) but comes at a higher risk of recurrence and the need for additional radiation.

Patient Query/inquiry: I have two tumors close together in the 3 and 4 o'clock position. Together they cover a 5cm (2cm each) area. I have DD breasts but my surgeon says I need a mastectomy. Is this the right treatment for me?
Patient Insight: Choice between lumpectomy and mastectomy depends on personal preferences and both options are reasonable. Key factors include size of tumor (lumpectomy better for smaller tumors), reconstruction potential (will there be enough tissue left over after lumpectomy for reconstruction), proximity to chest wall (mastectomy better if tumor close to chest wall) and willingness to put up with radiation (lumpectomy requires radiation). An awesome list of additional considerations in 'Interesting Followup' tab

Patient Insight: Losing Estrogen can have different effects, so it's reccomended to take it slow and start with Tamoxifen instead of getting the surgery righ away. Previewing ovarian suppression with lupron and laparoscopic oopherectomy instead of hysterectomy is also an option. Finally, the OP said that she would start Tamoxifen, then monthly zoladex once her period starts, then then think about oopherectomy because its easing into the surgery better.

Specific Patient Profile: Stage IIA ER+/PR+, HER2- IDC
Patient Insight: The body can react to the surgeries in different ways, the sudden absence of estrogen in your system can cause physical changes that can be positive or negative. Many say that the hysterectomy is not necessary more so a laporascopic oopherectomy. Before going through with the surgery recommended to take ovary suppression drugs such as Lupron or Zoladex to see how the body will react without the estrogen. If negative effects than try transitioning to the surgery with the Tamoxifen and suppression drugs.

Specific Patient Profile: Stage IIA ER+/PR+, HER2- IDC
Patient Insight: A hysterectomy is invasive and isnt very necessary even when being extremely thorough. More so an oopherectomy which is a factor in hormone dispersal and menopause. It would be a better idea to transition into the surgery before making a decision, staying on the Tamoxifen and taking ovary suppression drugs to see how the body will respond to the surgery.

Oncotype DX test isn't for node-positive cancer. Topic: Confused as why everyone seems to have surgery first

Neoadjuvant therapy is often used for aggressive tumors including HER2+ and TNBC. Neoadjuvant treatment can help understand if tumor responds to the treatment being administered and can allow patient to do a less drastic surgery (lumpectomy vs. mastectomy)

Topic: How have friendships changed for you?
Patient Query/inquiry: Patient is asking about how people's relationships chnage after they get diagnosed with cancer
Patient Insight: Different people handle things differently. Some friends will be very understanding and easy to talk to about cancer. Others will be awkard and open. This is usually not because they are insensitive, but because they don't know what to say and are uncomfortable with the situation. In this case, it's important to give them some time to acclimate as it is hard to see a friend diagnosed with cancer. It is normal for relationships with family and friends to change but it is important to let them run their course.

Topic: How have friendships changed for you?
Patient Insight: The best thing to do when navigating relationships during cancer treatment, is to not expect all your family and friends to be there for you like you expect them to be. Some of them will not know what to say or act which is okay, because it is important to remember that this is new territoryfor them as well. It is also okay to allow relationships to run their course because it is only natural.

Patient Query/inquiry: Patient is inquiring if BC spreads to the lymph nodes or to other organs
Patient Insight: Cancer cells are always in the body's bloodstream, and may stay dormant or may awaken later. If its not in the lymph nodes, this reduces the chance of it coming back, but cancer can spread even without lymph node involvement, as the cells are almost certainly always present. Prognosis for cancer returning is the same whether its found early or when the patient becomes symptomatic. Its best to focus on the present and not worry about what ifs.
Cancer can metastasize via the blood stream, lymphatic system or regionally to nearby tissue. Therefore, lymph node involvement is not always the next stage of BC.

There are cancer cells in the lymphatic system and in the bloodstream, which may be domant and have the possibility to become active in the future at any point. As of right now, the biotechnology behind trying to detect small cancer cells is too complicated. It is suggested to focus on your health at this stage and let the rest work itself out. Having routine scans once a year helps minimize anxiety.

Specific Patient Profile: Her mom's up for mastectomy in the next few days and she'll be having her left breast removed. She had her biopsy last week and the results show there are cancer cells on her lymph nodes. She was told the next step may be radiation or chemotheraphy
Patient Insight: After the mastectomy the pathologist will look at the tumor closely. Staging might change because it partly depends on the maximum size of the tumor and sometimes the mammograms/ultrasounds are not as precise. After the surgery, patient will probably have drains - tubes stitched or taped into the skin, to help drain fluid/blood from the incision. She may need to sleep upright for a bit & she will need some help around the house. Pain is usually well managed with medication. Decisions regarding chemotherapy are based on how aggressive the tumor is, its spread, its response to hormonal treatments, and the patient's ability to tolerate chemo side effects. Depending on her hormonal receptor status, she may also qualify for something called OncotypeDX where they analyze the tumor and try to predict its risk of recurrence. That can also help with the decision to pursue or skip chemo. Radiation is what is used in the area to kill any cells that might escape surgery. It tends to cause fatigue and skin damage but is by most accounts easier to deal with than chemo.

Patient Query/inquiry: What is the difference between stage IIA and IIB?
Specific Patient Profile: New lumpectomy patient, Oncotype score 12,
Patient Insight:
Staging is not done until after surgery and the completion of post-operative pathology. This is the breakdown of staging as per as the site: 
 Stage IIA: 
 - No tumor in breast but cancer (>2mm) is found in 1 to 3 axillary lymph nodes or in lymph nodes near breast bones. 
 - Tumor measures 2 cm or smaller and has spread to axillary lymph nodes
 - The tumor is between 2cm and 5 cm and has not spread to axillary lymph nodes. 
 
 Stage IIB: 
 - Tumor is between 2cm and 5 cm; small groups of breast cancer cells (between 0.2mm and 2mm) are found in lymph nodes.
 - Tumor is between 2cm and 5 cm; cancer has spread to 1-3 axillary lymph nodes near the breastbone. 
 - Tumor is larger than 5cm but has not spread to the axillary lymph nodes.

Specific Patient Profile: Chemotherapy AC + T (Taxol), Hormonal Therapy (Arimidex), Radiation Therapy (Whole-breast)
Patient Insight:
When concerned about experiencing any pain or symptoms, it is best to check with the doctor. Also, getting a PET scan clears all doubts about metastasis. If both confirm that there is no metastasis, it is possible that worrying or stress might be causing the pain. Injury, sleeping wrong, pinched back nerve etc. can be the reasons behind the pain. 
 Having undiagnosed pain might not be related to the breast cancer but that does not mean that it does not require medical attention. Seeing an orthopedist and getting an MRI scan done can help.
